children.name: to be unable to do sth
▪ ‘Will you help me move this?’ ‘I’m sorry, I can’t - my back’s still giving me trouble.’can’t/cannot do something
examples: ▪ Louise can’t see anything without her glasses.
▪ He couldn’t remember where he had left the car.
▪ I could never have climbed that ridge - I’m too out of shape.
▪ Scientists still cannot explain exactly how the virus reproduces.
▪ Sarah could not understand why anyone would want to hurt her.

children.name: not be able to do sth
children.definition: not be able to do something  - use this especially in the past or future tense: ▪ Unfortunately, I wasn’t able to help them.▪ I’m afraid I won’t be able to come to the meeting after all.▪ The doctor told Tina she wouldn’t be able to have children.▪ I’ve looked all over the house but I haven’t been able to find my keys anywhere.

children.name: not be in a position to do sth
children.definition: not be in a position to do something/be in no position to do something   informal to not be able to do something because you do not have enough knowledge, money, or authority: ▪ I’m afraid I’m not in a position to answer your questions.▪ Local school boards are in no position to pay for the extra cost of the curriculum.scarcely/hardly in a position to do something▪ The US is hardly in a position to criticize other countries for wasting energy supplies.

children.name: be incapable /not be capable B2
children.definition: be incapable/not be capable  to not have the physical or mental ability to do something - often used when you are criticizing someone:
examples: be incapable/not be capable of
▪ Matthew seemed to be incapable of keeping a job.
▪ She’s no longer capable of taking care of herself.
▪ Nero was a cruel man, utterly incapable of pity or sympathy.
incapableadjectivekhông đủ khả năng; bất tài; bất lực
unable to do something
_He seems incapableofwalkingpast a music shop without going in and buying another CD.
_I think she's incapableoflove.

children.name: inability to do sth
children.definition: inability the fact of being unable to do sth, used especially when you are annoyed with them because you think they are too weak, lazy etc to do it:
examples: inability to do something
Alcoholism can result in an inability to cope.
the government’s inability to enforce the ceasefire
Her actions show an inability to distinguish between fantasy and reality.somebody’s inability to do something
He even blamed his parents for his inability to make friends.
Voters are becoming frustrated at the inability of the administration to do anything about the debt crisis.

children.name: be unable to do sth
children.definition: be unable to do something  especially written to not be able to do something, especially something important that you want to do or need to do:
examples: ▪ He lay awake all night, unable to sleep.
▪ The surgery left her unable to walk for nearly three months.
be unable to dosth
to not be able to do something
_We were unable to contact him at the time.

children.name: not know how to do sth
children.definition: not know how to do something  to be unable to do something, especially something practical, because you have not learned how to do it:
examples: ▪ I didn’t know how to drive a car till I was 28.
▪ A lot of the doctors here still don’t know how to use the new equipment.

children.name: not be equipped
children.definition: /be ill-equipped   to be unable to do something because you do not have the right training or experience: not be equipped/be ill-equipped to do something▪ The young teacher wasn’t equipped to deal with such a difficult class.▪ The organization is ill-equipped to deal with the problems it may encounter.not be equipped/be ill-equipped for▪ After so many years in prison, Victor was not equipped for life on the outside.

children.name: ability
children.definition: the state of being able to do sth
examples: ability to do sth
the ability to walk
The health center serves all patients, regardless of their ability to pay.
Our ability to think and speak makes us different from other animals.
Luckily, she had innate ability to judge people quickly and accurately.

children.name: capability
children.definition: the ability of a person, machine etc to do sth, especially sth difficult that needs a lot of knowledge, skill, advanced equipment etc: năng lực, khả năng
examples: the country’s manufacturing capability
capability to do sth
Does the company have the capability to change to meet market needs?
With the new machines we finally have the capabilitytodo the job properly.
It is unclear whether the country has the capability to produce nuclear weapons.
beyond your capability
I can speak French, but simultaneous translation isbeyondmycapabilities(= too difficult ).
Man Ray explored the capabilities of the camera to their fullest extent.
capability of doing something
This computer system gives the user the capability of accessing huge amounts of data.

children.name: capacity
children.definition: (especially of a person or organization) the ability to do a particular thing - use this especially about a very great ability to do sth or to behave in a particular way: khả năng

children.name: capacity for
examples: He has an enormous capacity for hard work.
Cheryl’s capacity for understanding and compassion is impressive.

children.name: capacity to do sth
examples: Children have a remarkable capacity to learn language.

children.name: power
children.definition: a natural ability to do sth, especially to see, hear, speak etc: khả năng, năng lực

children.name: the power of sight/speech/hearing etc
examples: She was so surprised that for a few seconds she lost the power of speech.
The ostrich is a bird that no longer has the power of flight.
He was so shocked by what happened to his parents that he lost the power of speech.

children.name: power to do sth
examples: Doctors cannot explain why some people lack the power to fight off the disease.
The surgeon did everything in her power to save him.

children.name: powers
children.definition: powers of judgement/reasoning/persuasion etcthe ability to do sth that involves mental effort or skill, such as persuading, forming an opinion, thinking etc: năng lực, khả năng (trí óc)
examples: This problem is designed to test your powers of observation.
Teachers have the responsibility to develop students’ powers of critical thinking.
She impressed us all with her dazzling intellectual powers.

children.name: faculties
children.definition: faculty the natural abilitity that everyone normally has, for example the ability to think, see, hear, and speak: khả năng
examples: As we age we begin to lose some of our faculties.
the patient’s mental faculties
Even at the age of 100, she stillhadall her faculties.
faculty of
the faculty of sight/ speech
in full possession of all your faculties(= able to see, hear, think etc in the normal way )
Although he was dying, he remained in full possession of his faculties.

children.name: resources
children.definition: qualities such as courage and a strong mind that you need in order to deal with a difficult situation: tiềm lực
examples: She’s tough - I’m sure she has the emotional resources to handle it.
The new work stretches the physical resources of the company’s dancers.
He proved that he has considerableinner resources.

children.name: brilliant
children.definition: extremelyclever andskilfulat something, so that peopleadmireyou a lot: tài giỏi
examples: ▪ Have you seen her dance? She’s absolutely brilliant.
▪ Paganini was a brilliant violinist, famous for his technical skill in both playing and composing music.
brilliance[U]
▪ Hendrix’s brilliance as a rock guitarist remains unsurpassed, even to this day.

children.name: brilliant atespecially British
examples: ▪ She’s brilliant at handling difficult clients.

children.name: outstanding
children.definition: so good at doing sth that you are noticeably much better than other people who do the same thing: nổi bật, nổi trội
examples: Woods is an outstanding golf player.
The book is a series of interviews with outstanding artists and writers.
A lot of my teachers were good, but Farley was outstanding.

children.name: great
children.definition: great actor/player/scientist etcone of the best actors, players etc in the world, and famous and respected because of this: giỏi
examples: ▪ Olivier was a great actor.
▪ Some of the world’s greatest athletes will be competing in the Olympic Games.
▪ McEnroe was possibly the greatest tennis player of all time.

children.name: excellent
children.definition: extremely good at sth: xuất sắc
examples: Andrew had always been an excellent student.
She’s enthusiastic and hardworking and has the potential to be an excellent teacher.

children.name: good
children.definition: able to do something well:
examples: ▪ The school orchestra is surprisingly good.

children.name: good singer/ player/ teacher etc
examples: ▪ Frank had always been a good football player, and it was no surprise when he was chosen for the team.
▪ I can refer you to a good dentist.
be good atbe able to do something well:
▪ When she was at school she was good at art.
▪ She loves her job, and she’s very good at it.
▪ You’ve never been much good at lying.
▪ Robson is particularly good at dealing with people, and should make an excellent manager.

children.name: be good with sb/sthbe good at dealing with someone or something
examples: ▪ Mrs. Hill is very good with children.
▪ The two Drew girls are unusually good with animals.

children.name: be good with your handsbe good at making or repairing things with your hands
examples: ▪ Jeremy’s good with his hands - he built our kitchen cupboards.

children.name: proficient
children.definition: having reached an acceptable standard in sth, by learning or practising it: thành thạo, giỏi, chuyên gia
examples: proficiency[U]
▪ Once children have achieved a certain proficiency in reading, they prefer to read silently rather than aloud.

children.name: proficient in
examples: ▪ Before you can study at a British university, you have to be proficient in English.

children.name: proficient skier/ climber/ actor etc
examples: ▪ The black runs are for proficient skiers only.

children.name: able
children.definition: good at doing sth, especially at doing a difficult or important job that involves a lot of responsibility: có năng lực
examples: Mrs Thomas is a very able teacher.
She was widely regarded as one of the most able members of the president’s staff.

children.name: capable
children.definition: sb who is capable can be trusted to do a job or piece of work well and without needing other people’s help or advice: có năng lực, có khả năng
examples: Mr. Young is a very capable attorney.
The team desperately needs a capable quarterback.

children.name: competent
children.definition: sb who is competent has enough skill and knowledge to be able to do sth to a high or satisfactory standard: giỏi
examples: Competent skiers should find no difficulty with the course.
Though the country is poor, the doctors and nurses are qualified and competent.

children.name: highly competentvery competent
examples: Tomita is a highly competent translator.

children.name: competent in
examples: New students are expected to be competent in mathematics.

children.name: good at doing a lot of different things
versatile
children.definition: good at doing a lot of different things and able to learn new skills quickly and easily: đa tài, “đa năng”
examples: Meryl Streep is a wonderfully versatile actress.
Few musicians are as versatile as he is: he plays, composes, arranges, and teaches.
a very versatile performer
a more versatile workforce
versatility[U]
Hegley’s outstanding versatility as an all-round entertainer

children.name: all-rounder
children.definition: British sb who is good at doing a lot of different things: người toàn diện
examples: We’re looking for a good all-rounder -- someone who can run the office, deal with customers’ complaints, and so on.
At the school, children were encouraged to be ‘all-rounders’ - they were to aim for success in games as well as study.

children.name: to be able to do sth
▪ ‘I don’t think Mike can type.’ ‘Yes, he can.’can do something
examples: ▪ He can run faster than me.
▪ Can you see the TV, or should I move?
▪ This program can translate your e-mail into other languages.
▪ How many hamburgers do you think you can eat?
▪ Adrian could read when he was four.
▪ If we had a boat we could row across to the island.
▪ Why didn’t they ask me? I could have done it for them for half the price.

children.name: be able to do sth
children.definition: be able to do something  if you are able to do something, you can do it - use this especially about something that needs a lot of effort, skill, or knowledge: ▪ Those bags look really heavy - are you sure you’ll be able to carry them on your own?▪ After the accident it was a long time before she was able to walk again.▪ To take the class, you have to be able to use a computer.be able to▪ My grandpa’s getting old now and he can’t do all the things he used to be able to.

children.name: be capable of sth
children.definition: be capable of something  to have the ability, energy, or qualities needed to do something, especially something very difficult or unusual - use this about people or machines:
examples: ▪ He’s a very angry kid, but he’s not capable of murder.be capable of doing something
▪ The missiles are capable of travelling about 700 miles.
▪ Around 7 or 8, children are already capable of making their own moral evaluations.
be perfectly capable of doing somethingused to emphasize that you are definitely capable of doing something
▪ Leave the boy alone, I’m sure he’s perfectly capable of fixing it himself.
capable ofsth/doing sth
having the ability, power or qualities to be able to do something
_Only the Democratic Party is capable of running the country.
_A force 10 wind is capable of blowing the roofs off houses.
_When she's drunk she's capable of saying (= likely to say) awful, rude things.
_I think your plan is capable of being (= could be) improved.

children.name: have the ability to do sth
children.definition: have the ability to do something  to be able to do something, especially something that is unusual or that most people cannot do:
examples: ▪ She seemed to have the ability to make people do anything she wanted.
▪ I believe the team definitely has the ability to win the championship.

children.name: be equipped to do sth
children.definition: be equipped to do something   to be able to do something, especially to deal with a particular problem, because you have been properly prepared or had the right training: ▪ By the end of the course, students should be equipped to deal with any business situation.▪ The emergency services are well equipped to cope with disasters of this kind.

children.name: know how to do sth
children.definition: to be able to do something, because you know a way of a doing it, especially something practical such as operating a machine:
examples: ▪ Do you know how to use this computer?
▪ I’d turn the thing off if only I knew how.
know how to dosth biết làm thế nào để
to be able to do something because you have the necessary knowledge
_Do you know how to print on this computer?

children.name: have it in you
children.definition: to have the ability and the qualities of character needed to do something difficult, especially when you or other people doubt that you can do it: ▪ I admired the way you refused to let him bully you - I didn’t think you had it in you.have it in you to do something▪ No one thought I would win, but I knew I had it in me to do it if I really tried.

children.name: be in a position to do sth
children.definition: be in a position to do something   to have enough knowledge, money, or equipment to do something: ▪ Once the loan is paid off, Jones will be in a position to run the casino himself.▪ We will have to run more tests before we are in a position to say whether the document is authentic or not.be in a good/excellent/better position to do something▪ When I’ve read the whole report I’ll be in a better position to comment.

children.name: weak
children.definition: adjectiveBELOW STANDARD yếu

children.name: below standard; not good enough, especially in ability, skill or quality
examples: _He was always weakat/inlanguages but strong at/in science.
_Our quiz team is a bit weakonsport.
_In the end I think the film was spoilt by a weak story line.

children.name: amateur
children.definition: nounnghiệp dư

children.name: disapprovingsomeone who does not have much skill in what they do
examples: _I won't be giving them any more work - they're a bunch of amateurs.

children.name: hopeless
children.definition: adjective không có năng lực

children.name: completely without skill at a particular activity
examples: _I'm hopelessatsports.
_He's a hopeless cook.
